div.head: Egyptian Magic
div.p: The discoveries daring recent years both in Egypt and Chaldea have given an entirely new aspect to the subject of magic, formerly regarded as an evil invention of the priestly magicians to enslave tho minds of the igno­rant. In magic we have man's private sys­tem of natural philosophy, based on practical experience, and many of these dednetion- survived and became the basis of religions teachings or soieutific faots. The numerous editions of the Book of the Dead, a mioe of information on magic, published by the Trnstees of the British Mnsenm, afford ns a knowledge of the main teachings of Egypt, while the large number of magical tablets from the library at Nineveh, pnblished and translated by Mr. R. Campbell Thompson, enlighten us upon the chief teatnres of Baby Ionian magic. It is particularly interesting to compare the two systems, for they sh-.w a carious difference both in origin aDd future development.

In Egypt (says a writor in our London con­temporary the "Globe") magic reaohos back to an immense antiquity,and even where literature oeases we can trace its existence by certain signs or objeota placed in the tombs of the dead. In Egypt it presents more primitive ideas than in Chaldea, and is, therefore, more interesting to the student. Fortunately, Egypt affords ns a slight claa t) ths gaieiis of magic, especially the earlier firm of spoken magic. All spoken magio depended upon the right pronunciation aui tone of certain words oalied "words of power," or, rather, to take another meaning, "words that compelled." Those words might be names of gods or demons, or, indeed, the names of individuals, for the knowledge of a name gave the one who ottered it power over the owner. There were also certain mystic words, often very grotesque, which possessed great power. It does not seem wrong to see a a very simple origin for this system. In the earliest days of man's oooopation of the Nile valley there most have been a very limited number of individuals, and language was in its infancy, words only coming into existones as required to name or describe certain objects, the vooabnlary growing as civilisation progressed. In this primitive stage language was oonfined to the more intelligent of the community, and the faot that by the utterance of a certain word a man was made to perform certain acts or to bring certain objects was to the ignorant a mysterioaa manifestation of power, and the words were the compulsion to bring about the desired lesuk In this way there grew up certain formu'ac, or simple names and words that were of occult power, and would act not only on men, bot on gods and demons also. A carious survival of this belief in the power of the knowledge of the name of a being or objeot is preserved in the Bible. After the Creation all the animals were brought to Adam, that he might give them their names, for by doing to he gained domi­nion over them.

It was an easy step from spoken magio to ceremonial magic. It was found that certain aots, each as dancing, certain gestures, had an effect upon human beings ; that they would also be effective upon those whom the de­parted might encounter in the next world was a natural conclusion. The graphic instinct, shown in the lowest types of man, which is one of the strongest differences be ween him and the anthropoid ape, next comes into play, and the picture of a man, a god, demon, or animal oarries with it power over the efforts depicted. In Babylonia we have no trace of these primitive stages, for in the earliest texts Chaldean magio had become systematised. In Babylonia religion and temple ceremonial was perfected at a much earlier period than in Egypt, and man did not worship his gods by compelling them to do what he required, bat by association with them, feeding with them in the sacrifices, and observing a loving filial relationship with them.

Magic has two oourtes open to it when it reaches its fallest development. It either be­comes absorbed into religion, with a more elaborate ritual and liturgy, or it becomes elementary science. In Egypt the former was the case. All Egyptian magic became absorbed first in the "Book of the Dead," then in the Funeral Ritaals, such as the ceremony of ihe "Opening of the Month," the funeral service of Nile-land, and, as M. Me ret has shown, the whole daily service of the Theban temple was a magical cer^moi y which brought the god to life eaoh day. Babyiouian primitive magic, ' which peopled ad objects in natnre with in dwelling spirits, gradnolly led to a class ficatinn of these spirits into special hierarchies—which was, indeed, a primitive scientific grouping. Clond and storm demons in their ritnal laid the groundwork of meteorology.Star and planet rituals passed from astrology to astronomy. Demoniacal possession supplied the elements of medicine, and the herbs used in the oharms became drugs. Egypt shows no traoe of this phase. Even the astronomical texts show no magical or scientific knowledge, and the Ebers medical papyrus owes little to magio and more to common-sense. The resalt of this divergence ia subsequent developments is that Egyptian magio died with the fall of the religion. Chal­dean lived long after the temples of Chaldea were in mins—was studied in the Jewish schools of Babylon and Borsipps, to be trans­mitted in the form of the Black Art and psendo-scienoe to Europe by the Arabs, and thns to live in some sense to-day.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Quarantine restrictions as against plague are now applied to arrivals in Egyptian ports from India.
An Improvement,
The roe Zervndachi, Cairo, has been metalled and is now free from the alarming rots that made it till lately a switchback.
Victoria House.
The ladies of the executive committee of this institution will be "at home" at Viotoria House on Thursday, 29th inst.
Public Health Dept.
Mr. Rnssell Barrett has been authorised to practise as a dentist, M. Selim Rhonry as a physioian, and Mme Amelia Nodary as a midwife.
A History of Egypt.

A new history of Egypt is to be published this month. It will extend from the earliest times to the Persian oonquest. The author is Mr. James H. Breasted, Professor of Ecyotology and Oriental History, eto., in the University of Chicago.
Soldier's Suicide.

Having beard that a oonnoil of discipline has sentenced him to seven days' imprison­ment for disnbed'enoe of orders, a so'dier qnartered in Abdeen barracks committed sni- cide on Tnesday by shooting himself with bis rifle, in bis room.
Excavations at Elephantine.

Dr. Riibensohn. who has been af work this season on behalf of the Berlin Mnsenm at Elephantine Island, has excavated a part of the anoient town there. He expects to return to the work next season as there is still a great deal to be done.
Mysterious Death,

A native woman was found dead in her honse near Mafroura yesterday with some hams on her body. The body was removed to hospital for a post-mortem examination, and meantime the polios are trying to solve the mystery of the woman's death.
Egyptological Lecture.

Mr. Q'enfell will eive his leotnre on the ex­cavation for papyri at Oxyrynchushy the Greco- Roman branch of the Egypt Exploration Fand on Monday, 19th inst., at 6 p.m., at the Con­tinental Hotel, under the anspioes of the Century Club.
Shepheara's.

We may remind our readers of the garden fete which is to be held to morrow night at Shepheard's. Besides snob attractions as oonfetti, serpentines, fireworks, etc., the band of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers and the Tsigane orchestra will play alternately in the garden from 9 o'clock to midnight, when danoing will oommenoe.
Grand Continental Hotel.

The ramonr as to the sale of the Grand Continental Hotel at Cairo is to the effect that it has not been sold to the Egyptian Estates, Limited, bat that the latter oomp&ny have only aoted as brokers in the basiness on behalf of some London capitalists, who, so it it said, intend, to oonvert the sit9 into magnificent galleries of shops.
Guide Book for Visitors.

Mr. C. Aqnilina, proprietor of the Carlton Hotel, Bnlkeley. has issued a handy little guide-book for the benefit of the hotel's gnests and the tourist in general. Mr. Aqnilina says be does not presame in these pages to give anything like an exhaustive description of everything there is to be seen in Alexandria and Cairo and the environs, hat to present a concise acoonnt as to the manner in which visitors may profitably spend the time at their disposal in each one of the two great cities of the East ; a summary of Egyptian history and geography, the varioae creeds. religions, and customs of the anoient Egyptians, Arabs, and Copts, eto., is not given ; Mr. Aqnilina aims more particularly at presenting a hook to serve as a valuable aid to those tourists having only a limited period to spend in Lower Egypt and thns to give a brief guide, to the principal attractions and monuments in Cairo and Alex­andria. The book, which is en'itled "The Little Treasure," is well got op and printed, .and ontains a mass of nsefnl information.

div.head: THE YEMEN EXPEDITION. FEIZI I'ACHA RETREATS FROM SANA.
div.p: The "Times" correspondent at Constanti­nople states that itis reported that Ahmed Feizi Pacha, after prolonged sorties with 10,000 men, has been obliged to make a retreat from Sana. The breakdown of the transport arrange­ments has made a sustained campaign impos­sible. Ahmed Fe zi Pacha, oat of despair, has resigned his command, but hia resignation has not been aocepted. The Government is doing all that is possible, but the laok of monoy, the relnotanoe of the Turkish soldiers to serve in the Yemen, and the unbusinesslike methods of the Turkish administration render their efforts nugatory.

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR DEBATE.
div.p: A stirring debate took plaoe in the Honse of Commons on the subject of Chinese labour. The Opposition was submitted to vigorous oritioism. No Royal Commission of enquiry is to be appointed. div.head: MENA HOUSE HOTEL
div.p: THE NUNGOVICH APPEAL.
CAIRO JUDGMENT REVERSED.

This morning judgment was given by the Mixed Court of Appeal at Alexandria in one of the most interesting capes of pre-emption that has ever come before an Egyptian Tri bnnal. This was the appeal of the Nnngo- vich Hotels Company agaitst thejadgmeDt of the Cairo Mixed Court of 1st Instance, which upheld the claim of Dr. Bifky Pacha and the Princess, his wife, to exercise their right of pre-emption in the matter of the purchase of Mena House Hotel by the Non- govich Hotels Company.

The appelants maintained that none of the rights and privileges of persons olaiming to pre empt could be invoked in the present case. In regard to the position of the property the donble contignity, an indispensable prior con­dition of pre-emption in the oase. of rural pro­perty, snoh as the Mena House, Hotel, was absent. Moreover, no servitude existed and the objeot of the claimants to pre empt was merely a speculative deal, sinhe it was the hotel qua hotel and not as an estate that was the object of the pre emption in this case, and pre emption oannot be exercised in the oaae of a commercial or industrial establishment. The arguments of the claimants to pre-empt were based on the faot that the estate in qnestion could not be qualified as "rural" bat as "urban" and therefore contignity only on one side of the property constituted a sufficient basis on which to exeroiee the right of pre­emption.

The appeal oase came before the Seoond Chamber, presided over by Jadge Moriondo. The Coart quashed the judgment of the lower Coart, non-saited Dr. Rifky and the Princess, and ordered them to pay or sts.
Mattre Carton de Wiart was oonnsel for Dr. Rifky and Maltre Clsar Adda for the Nan- govich Hotels Company.

Faire les operations oi-dessns en Egypte et à l'etranger.
Enfin faire tontes operations se rattaohant aux objeta qui precedent, de mime qae pren­dre tontes participations dans des operations de cette nature.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: Another well has now been put down to the artesian Bopply in the oasis ofKharga; it dives an output of over 250 gallons per minute. This is an improvement on those already pot
down.

With the new and heavier machines which have now arrived well after well should be put down within the next oonple of months, each giving, it is hoped, equal if not better results than those obtained in the present instance.
It is encouraging to note that applications have already been received for several thousand feddats of land when the Corporation are ready to sell.
The railway concession has been signed and work on the formation has advanced some 50 kilometres on to the top of the plateau.
Platelaying is progressing slowly hot with the new rolling stook now in the country the advance of this work will be considerably quickened as soon as the stock is got to work.
Some of the new bogie stock is already running, while locomotives are in Alexandria, having arrived by the Creole Pri:ce.

div.head: CAIRO SCHOOL STRIKE
div.p: AN AMNESTY GRANTED.
LORD CROMER AND THE STRIKE.
His Excellency the Minister of Public Instruction has deoided to grant an amnesty to those students of the 8cho.nl of Agricnltnre who rcoently went oat on Btrike.
The following is the text of a letter sent by the Earl ot Cromer yesterday to his Exoellency on the subject of the strike:—
BRITISH AGENCY.
Caiko, 14th March, 1906.

Exoellency,—I have the honour to forward a petition which I have received from the students of the 8ohool of Agrionltnre. Your Exoellency will obsorve that the students ex­press ' very ainoere repentanoe" for their reoent conduot, and allege that they "aoted thonghtlessly, blindly following the example of other schools." They, therefore, ask that their reoent oondnot should be overlooked. I understand that yonr Excellenoy has received a similar representation.

The breach of discipline of which the stndents at the School of Agrionltnre have been guilty is unquestionably serious. They absented themselves after the Ministerial order of February 28th—which was issued by yonr Excellency's direction, and whioh, I am of opinion, was urgently demanded under the O'ronmstances bad been read to them. Never­theless, I am quite willing to believe that they were lei away by the bad example set to them by the students of the School of Law; aDd I have no reason to donbt that the expression of repentanoe which they have now oommanioated to yonr Exosllenoy and myself is sinoere. Under these oironmstanoes, I venture to re- oommsnd the petition of the stndents to yonr Excellency's favourable consideration.

It must, of coarse, be fatly understood that, now that fall pablioity has been given to the order of February 28 th, it will be impossible to plead ignorance of the regulations. That order mast, therefore, be Btrictly ap­plied if, in future, similar oases should un­fortunately arise.

I take this opportunity of alluding, briefly, to th9 faots oonneoted with the reoent in­cident at the School of Law. Had the al­leged grievances of the stndents at that Sohool been pat forward in a proper manner, yonr Excellency wonld, I do not donbt, have emsed oareful and impartial enquiry to be made into their natare. Unfortunately, the method adop­ted by the stndents in order to bring their grievances to notice was in the highest degree objeotionable. More than this, I gather, from the reports which I have rece'vei, that since the stndents returned to the Sohool their oon- daot has been far from satisfactory. They have, indeed, addressed a oommaaioation to yonr Excellency which, so far from mitigating, aggravates their previous offenoe. Even, how­ever, in their oase,I should be unwilling to take too severe a view of the oondoct of inexperien­ced young men, who have very possibly been led away by bad advioe. They mast, however, dearly understand that the maintenance of proper discipline in the colleges under yonr Excellency's direction comes before all other considerations. Indeed, inasmroh as these stu­dents are being prepared for the legal profes­sion, it would seem that they shoald be the first to set to their comrades an example of obedience to the law.

I wish to reiterate the statement which I made in a memorandum published a few days ago, namely, that enquiry into ths alleged grievances of these stadents will depend upon whether, "at the end of the session, the department of Public Instruction reports favour­ably on their work and general oondnot." I should add that unless this report is favour­able,* the qnestion may arise, not so mnoh of whether any enquiry should be made into the alleged grievanoes, hot rather of whether some fnrthet special measures shoald not be taken in or ter to enforoe discipline in this School.
I avail myself of th<s opportunity to renew to yonr Excellenoy the assurance of my high consideration.
(Signed): CROMER.
His Exoellency
Hussein Fakhry Paoha, K.C.M.G., Minister of Public Instruction.

div.head: BIG GAME SHOOTING
div.p: IN THE SUDAN.
MR. JOHNSON'S EXPERIENCES.

Mr. J. C. Johnson, jaD., of Messrs. J. C. Johnson & Co., Ltd, cement manufacturers at Gateshead on-Tyne and Greechithe, author of the work "Sport on the Bine Nile," returned to Cairo last week, aPer an absence of about three months, from a successful shooting ex­pedition - the fifth he has undertaken—on the Bine Nile and Dindet River. In the latter district he was for the space if 24 days engaged in traoking elephants throngh a desolate coun­try overgrown with forest and jangle and destitute of human habitations. In these regions, between the extreme limit of the inhabited Sudan and Abyssinia, the only food available for the sustenance of Mr. John­son's personal servants and a company of 20 soonts, the latter drawn from among the natives of the inhabited districts, was the game secured by his own gan.

Although on this occasion Mr. Johnson did not succeed in killing an elephant, as on his previous expedition, yet he bad a somewhat thrilling experience in meeting at each olose quarters an enormous ball elephant that it was important to secure an aooorate shot at that pre<i6e spot in the huge skull of the pachyderm wh ch covers the brain. He was traoking the animal with extreme diffioolty owing to the direotion of the wind, and while making a long detonr to oironmvent the herd by crossing their path ahead of them suddenly, on emerging from behind a screen of tall straw, he found himself praotioally overshadowed by the elephant, which was striding along, and he barely had time to take aim and fire hastily at the head of the beast and decamp as the elephant broke into a gallop.

On his return journey by the Bine Nile Mr. Johnson had a remarkable bag of hippopotami near the village of Rammash, district of Singa, bringing down three of these enormous brutes within the space of an honr with a 303 oarbico rifle, the only weapon used by him ror all kinds of game. In each oase the ballet entered the brain olose to the ear, bat in one instance it actually entered the brain by one ear and passed ont at the other without the slightest perforation cf the skin, which, although un­intentional, was a singular anl remarkable achievement.

Although at times he suffered from fever and the extreme heat Mr. Johnson enjoyed his trip immensely, and when he arrived in Cairo looked and felt very fit. He left Port Said on Sunday aooompanied by a faithful Sudanese servant, by the Orient mail liner Ortona for Naples on his retorn to England.

div.head: MISSIONARY WORK IN THE SUDAN
div.p: The party of missionaries sent ont to the Sudan by the Chnroh Missionary Sooiety in November last, at the instigation of Lord Cromer, arrived safely at their destination, Mocgalla, in January. It has now been prac­tically deoided to select another plaoe as the headquarters of the mission. After investigation by Dr. Cook (who arrived from Uganda some weeks in advanoe of the pioneer band) and oonBnltation with the Governor of the Bahr el Ghazal provinoe, it has been discovered that another district lower down the river offers mnoh greater opportunity for beginning mission work. There are several pagan tribes in that region. Those with whom the Chnroh Missionary Sooiety missionaries will at first have moBt todo are the Dinkas, a warlike people who have no king. Their only "religion" appears to he spirit- worship and the nse of charms.
The party consists of three clergymen, a doctor, an agrioaltnrist, and an instrnotor in industrial work.

Sir Auckland entered the East India Company's service r early half a oentory ago, and in 1880 he went to Egypt as a member of the International L:qoidation Committee, and stayed there as Controller- General, later becoming Financial Adviser to the Khedive. Sir A nokland received the thanks of Parliament for his labonrs, and he went baok to India to be Financial Member of the Viceroy's Connoil, taking op his administrative post in the North-Wert Provinoes in 1887.

div.head: THE LATE GEN. GATACRE
div.p: IIIS EGYPTIAN CAREER.

The late General Gatacre remained a briga- dier-geDeral on the Indian establii-hnient until July, 1897, when be returned home to assome command of an infantry brigade at Aldershot. He had only held this a few weeks when he was harried ont to Egypt to take charge of the British brigade daring the advanoe on and at the battle of the Atb ra, where his personal gallantry was once again oonspiononsly dis­played In the subsequent advance on Khar­toum General Gataore was given command of the British division, with Colonels N. G. Lyt­telton and Wanchope as hie brigadiers.Under hie command the division certainly was in a state of oonrtant readiness and hard fighting effioienoy ; bat here again he was generally considered to have oarried his theory that the British soldier is capable of unlimited physical endurance to unreasonable limits, and some of his precautions, such as that of making the whole divis:on sleep in their boots when not within measurable distance of the euemy, were rather severely commented on at the time. With his men, however, the general was on the whole extremely popular ; though he taxed them to the ntmost, he never made them do what he was not always willing to do himself, while no one could gainsay his per­sonal gallantry on the field of battR For hia services in the Sudan General Gataore was twice mentioned in despatches, was thanked by both Honses of Parliament, and received the Second Class of the Medjidieh and the K.O.B.

The new Cabinet is described as the most advanced yet seen in Franoe. It met yester day and deoided to oontinne the Chorob inventorying and to follow M. Ronvier's foreign polioy, especially as regards the Alge- oiras Conference. (

A French ministerial statement deolaies that the Government is determined to crush all resistance ,to the Separation Law. The Chamber gave a vote of confidence to the Government by 305 to 197. (Reuter.)
A declaration read to Parliament states that the Cabinet will apply the Separation Law with firmness and pradence, and that it will oontinne the foreign polioy of the f irmer Cabinet. Q
In oonseqnenoe of an interpellation on home polioy the Chamber passed a vote of, confi­dence in the Ministry by 305 votes against 197.

div.head: MALTA AND THE FLEET
div.p: DISMAY AT ITS WITHDRAWAL.
BY ONE OF THE GARRISON.

Thore is a British possession which on rues the Entente Cordiale. Dismay rtigns in the island of Malta. Undisguised alarm and appre­hension are written upon the features of its genial inhabitants, from hotel proprietor to shopkeeper and dhaisaman, as they try to realise all that is meant to them by the latest concentration scheme of the British Admiralty, which involves the withdrawal of the Medi­terranean F'eet a'most entirely from this his­toric station. It is like a man waking up to find a gold miae has been suddenly reft from him in the night. From Floriana to 8t. Elmo, from the lines of Verdala to the limits of Sliema, there is lamentation and monrning and woe. One party iB stricken dnmb. The extreme eeotioD, whose raison hitherto has been the assertion of a so-called national policy, in opposition to British interests, are brooght up short against the adamantine fact that they have been qnarrelling with nothing less than their bread and butter.

A prominent speoimen of this party, a trades­man in the Strada Reale, who has made his living entirely ont of the soldier and sailor officer, not long ago, in a character­istically vehement disquisition on the natio­nal qoeation, assured me that both garrison and fleet remained at Malta solely on the sufferance of the Maltese "nation" ; that the latter, who had besieged and overpowered Napoleon's army in Valetta, oould, if they so pleased, bundle ns ont of the plaoe to-morrow. Poor man ! when I visited him before leaving, I found a pale ghost of the former self-oonfldent and bellicose patriot. "Santa Maria! it is rain for me, for as all 1" he exclaimed, with despairing gesticulation, and I had not the heart to rub it into him any farther. He knew, they all knew, what a loss of untold gold the with­drawal of the fleet will rne&D. And it is bat a step, they say, to the redaction of the garrison as well. Thousands of men will lose their employment on the dockyard and wharves Thousands of boatmen, whose many-oolonred dhaisas cover the interminable waterways of the Grand Harbonr, will feel the pinoh of the coming time, the bumboat people, the frnit sellers, the carrozzi drivers, the mnltitn- dinons beggars who hannt every garlic-smelling street, the vendors of laoe and filigree, will realise as never before the dependence of their fortunes on the open-handed Briton.

For not only does the sailor, by reason of his aooumnlated savings when at sea, poor ont his money like water as soon as be gets ashore, bat the presence of the fleet has always largely augmented the number of British residents in the shape of families and relatiocs of officers serving in the Mediterranean, who have eontinnally found Malta a very conve­nient residential oentre. Large numbers of these are already paoking np, and even as 1 write the flight has began. The generally- expressed opinion is that henceforth, if no change of polioy takes place, the sooial rain of Malta is complete, and the long-famed Valetta season may be ooasidered a thing of the past. The Mediterranean Fleet has always contained a considerable percentage of rich men who took a large share in the sport and sooial festivities of the island. Oa the polo ground and racecourse the Navy could hold their own with anyoue, and the danoes on the battleships in the harbonr were looked forward to beyond any in the plaoe; while, if the soldiers gave a ball, the blnejaoket was always at band with his banting and unrivalled talent as a deoorator.

It is inevitable, therefore, that the withdraw- wal of such finanoial resource" which a bi j fleet represents, will se^. ^sly affect the sooial outlook. The garrison,even if not also reduced, as many soldiers, who might go,fervently hope, and as is by no means improbably oinnot support the same harden alone. What will become, then, of the great "Fishing Fleet" which has invariably defended on the island for the winter season ? Hitherto, eaoh year, when the son has travelh d southwards to the line, when the moistnre-laden air beoama a trifle oooler and the sirocco less frequent, every steamer has deposited a living load on pleasure bent. Hotels, flats, and houses have had their accommodation taxed to the utmost Few men have arrived with the' Fishing Fleet," but mothers by the score with marriageable daughters, grass widows, society failures or soiled goods, wives, sisters, oousins, and aunt* of the fleet and garrison, a multitudinou; gathering of femininity, good, bad, and indiflo rent, ponr into the plaoe.

Young aDdold, titled and nutitled, moneyed, but more often moreyless, those who havo fai'ed to secure any fish in the home waters set forth with wits and experience matured to net the big garrisons abroad. Above all, the fleet and garrison at Malta are heavily officered and form a big fixed shoal inoapable of flight, and although mo3<ly small fry, the fiiherwo men have hungered too long to be partionla*- about their catch. There is indeed no limit to their energy, and the disappointed oast the:r nets with advanoing years even forther eastwar 1 still. Is it all at an end—the brilliant "whit i nights" at the opera, the succession of dances, the moonlignt pionios.the' Maltaengagementi," the eating and drinking, the squabbling, back biting, costly dressing, the rise in prices si! ionnd, and rivalry in everything ? For thes • are the constituents cf the "Malta season" in which the butterflies of the "Fishing Fleet" 'ceem tofiad such perennial debght, and npon which the astute "Maltes" bar. battened to his no small profit for so long that he never dreamed of ite possible transition.

div.p: It is offi tally intimated that the following officers, serving in Egypt, have passed the examination for pic motion to the next rank— Captain T. E. Bayley, 2Dth Hussars, D. A. A. and Q M. G.,;. Linutenapts J. G. Devenisb,

list.item: C. Adams and H. N. Young, Royal Innis- killing Foeiliers; Captain and Brevet Major

M. Finch, Captain A. G. E. Bingley, Lieu­tenants B. H. W. Taylor, J. Duberley, and L. W. Bird, Riyal Berkshire Regiment ; Lieute­nant B. Seymour, 1st Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps; Captain A. E. Molesworth and Lieutenant A. Brodhurst-Hill, Royal Dublin Fasiliers.

div.p: Captain C. H. E. Longhlin, Leinster Regi­ment, who latterly has been serving with the 4th (Uganda) Battalion King's African Rifles, has been promoted major. Major Lough'in originally entered the army as a private soldier and served in the ranks for over three years, getting his oommission in the Lrinstera in 1890. He has seen a good deal of service in East Atrioa and Central Afrioa, including the Uganda operations of 1898 (medal with clasp), and as a non-oommissioned officer he served in the Sadan Campaign of 1888, inoluding the ection of Gemaizah (medal with olasp, and hronzs star).

The King has been pleased to approve of the Africa General Service medal, with clasps, being granted to the forces employed in the recent military operations in Southern Nigeria, eabject to the claims being approved of by the Army Coune'1.
The old constitutional Force, commonly known as the Militia, it is announced, is to be given a brigade organisation with a proper staff. This has been promised from time imme­morial.

It is announoed that the Army Coanoil has decided to redace the infantry of the line by ten battalions, and that from the 1st April next—a pecnliatily appropriate date in many army matters—the 3rd and 4th Battalions of the Northumberland Fasiliers, Royal War­wickshire Regiment, Royal Fasiliers, Lanca­shire Fusiliers, and Worcestershire Regiment will be gradually absntbed. The c-ffioers and non-oommissioned tfficers for whom vacancies cannot be got in the 1st and 2 d Battalions will be given a choice of transfers to certain regiments. The most of the doomed battalions were formed in the spring of 1900, daring the early stages of the Boer War. If Mr. Haldane has nothing better to replace these ten batta­lions he should let well enough alone. It is all very (well to talk about the expansion of the militi^ and the special. training experiment which is to b8 oarried ont by selected batta- lionsfbut the latter is a tentative measure whilst the ten battalions are a substantial asset in the Empire's forces. It looks like the old familiar polioy of ontting down expenses for party purpose?.
Readers of the "Gazette" will recall the 3rd Battalion Royal Fusiliers, one of those to be disbanded, as a very smart battalion at Cairo and Alexandria in 1902-03.
The Tyne, depot$»ip of the Atlantic Fleet, will be recommissioned at Chatham on the 12th inst. for a second tarn of service in that capacity at "GiV*

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

Gold h»0 continued to flow into the Bank daring the past week, with the inevitable re­sult that loan rates have been put on a lower level all ronnd. It is evident, however, that the market is still in a very sensitive state. Loans and discount#, in the early days of the week, were very easy, but when it was seen that the discharge of Treasury bills on Wednes-. day to the extent of £2,000.000 brought very little money into the market, ra4es qniokty showed a harder tendency, especially the dis­count rate, which recovered from 3| to 8$%.

A lower level has, nevertheless, been reaohed, for although oall loans are somewhat patchy, ranging between 3} and 4}%, weekjy fixtures command only 3$%, at which rate also the India Coanoil have renewed loans for a month, whilst Stock Exchange settlement loans were done at 4$ as against 4f on the last occasion.

No great redaction on these rates oan be looked for in the . forthcoming week, for al­though the Bank of England has received a fair amount of gold since the returns were made np. constant withdrawals are taking place for Sooth America, and to the Bank als^ the market is still indebted. Whilst the French Exchange is weak at 25.15, the German rate, high as it is at 20.48, (hows a fall from last week's figure, and the American rate is on the downward move. ThnBank returns referred to were also not as favourable as was generally exnected. Troe, the proportion is higher at 47% but the other deposits show a redootion of £3,712,000, and although there is a de­crease ot £692,000 in public deposits, owing, of coarse, to the repayment of two millions of Treasury bills, revenue collections are evident­ly still heavily in progress, the balance at the awdit of the Government being nearly 17$ milliors. It appears that a portion of the gold received daring the past week has found its way into the provinces, and this, although weakening to the reserve, is gratifying as exhibiting increased activity in the trade of the country.
All things oorsidered. the outlook, although favourable, does not justify any very "bearish" view as regards loan and discount rates.
The Stook Markets.

It is pleasant to be able to record a very distinct improvement not only on the Stock Exchange.bat also in respeettohome and foreign politios. It seems now quite e'ear that what ever may follow from the Algeciras Conference, Germany hfcs no w nil for war, and is, equally with Franoe, showing signs of a desire to bring the deliberations to a satisfactory termination. When once rid cf ttbss lowering oloud, there seems every prospeot of things getting rapidly better. The trade reports of the oonntry are magnificent, and unless a set-back occurs, this progress promises to continue for the rest of the year, though probably the last month will show some falling-off. ^

The new members in the House of Commons are so taken up with finding their way about, and discussing all kinds of topics with their friends, that there doe? not seem any proRpeot of important legislation for fome time to oome. At the same time, Mr. Haldane, with his statesmanlike, diplomatic manner of handling the great army qnestion, meets with praise from all sides. It is felt that the party is more likely to be ran by the few strong men, which it undoubtedly contains, than by the weaker and more irresponsible members.

There is no more talk of heavy fail area to­day, the settling-day, notwithstanding th« depreciation of over £9.000,000 in one class of Beoarities alone, and there are general prediotions of considerable advances in mrst stooks before next settlement.
Gilt-edged Stook.

The increasing confidence of the "Honse" has given a very firm tone to the market for gilt-edged securities thronghont the week, and each day has seen a slight advancement in the price of Conso'.p. The resignation of the French Government failed to effect the spirit of optimism, and to night Consols leave off $ higher since our last at 90 Rxd. for oash and 90 $$xd. for the April account.
Foreign Bonds,

The exhibition of a more conciliatory atti tude on the part of Germany in regard to the points in dispute regarding Morocco, and the irospecta cf an amicable settlement being ■thortly arrived at, has been responsible for an •mprovemeot in basiness in this market, and though the French crisis caused some anxiety erday, this was soon dispelled when i became known that Paris was taking th< matter calmly. There has been a fair amoun* of baying of Rassian Fours, which havi advanoed to,84}, and some of the Japane-* 188063 have been in good demand, the Four' being Lett r at fOj.
Home Ralls.

W., which has an inorease of £8,000 o r the top of a simil* amount in 1905. Americans.

The American market had a (harp set-back early in the week, bat*from this it subsequently recovered, and since Wednesday a steady im­provement has been noticed. Egyptian Markets are supposed to be-ljV, aQd Salt and 8oda are quoted at the same figure. Bank of Roomania are very strong, and olose all bnyers at 9$.

The Egyptian Trust and Investment Com­pany's year ends this month, bat their report, which is being looked forward to with'keen interest, will not be out for some time. It is hoped that there will be a good dividend. The position of the oompany seems thoroughly sound, and the shares would appear to be cheap. div.head: A TALE OF THE SUDAN
div.p: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN OFFICER NATIVE QUEEN.

The main sretfs cf Mr. Rider Haggard's latest novel "The Way of the Spirit" are laid in the Sudan. Colonel Rupert Ullershaw, the hero; home on leave from Egypt, where he has highly distinguished himself, falls in love with the calculating Edith. They are married, only to separate after the wedding ceremony, Rnpert having to retarn to the Sudan to undertake a difficult secret mission. The villain is responsible for this separation, his machinations having resulted in the ohoice of Colonel Ullershaw for the dangerous diplomatic task.

It proves very dangerous. Rupert falls pri­soner to a revengeful Arab, who deprives him of a foot and an eye. He is rescued from death, however, by the roler of a little tribe who live in a wonderful oasis. The ruler is a obarmiog young woman, the Lady Tama, to whom Rupert has done a service, and who repays him by falling in love with him, mutilated as he is.

The reader will guess that she carries the unfortunate hero to her oasis, norsea his wounds, and suggests matrimony. Rnpert, though fisoinated. gently repels her advances and returns home. His wife shrinks with horror from him. Everybody thinks him dead. He decides to remain dead to everybody. Going back to the oasis, he live? with Tama as a brother with a eister. He will not marry her, even according to the onstom of the oonntry, because he already possesses a wife.

8o for years Rupert and Tama live in platonio friendship, ruling their people wisely and wall. Then it becomes known in Eogland that the Colonel Ullershaw whom none save the silent E lith have thought alive is hidden away in Egypt. It is necessary to seek him, sines the eynioal peer's death has made him Lord Dsvene. Edith, whosa views have been ohanged by the process of years—and the peerage, travels to the Sadan in company with the villain. Poor Rupert is called on to decide whether duty oalls him to his wife or his sister Tama. How he decides we oaunct tall—it would be a pity to give Mr. Haggard's story away.
As a work of art "The Way of the Spirit" cannot be praieed. Nevertheless, we have found it very interesting, and its moral - the beauty of rennnoiation—is admirable.

div.head: INFORMATIONS FINANCIERES
div.p: Ua oonirkre da Cairo lorit :

Un bon mouvement vient de se deasiner sar les actions de la New-Egyptian Company qui restaient depnia qae'que temps dans an Itat latent immlritl, et qui ont fait soudain un bond d'environ 5 shellings.
Cette hausae, pleinement jnatifile, n'est qu'un petit prllude et semble devoir Otre appelle à s'aoceatner dans . une me3ure beau ooup plus forte.
Tout d'abord, poor Texeroioe olOturl le 80 jain 1905, la Sooiltl a pn rlmanlrer lea 250 000 aotioDa à Lst 1 qui oompoaent son capital, d'un dividende de 2 ah. et demi.

En second lieu, en vertn d'nne concession aooordle par l'Etat, la New Egyptian Co. acquis le droit d'amender les banos de sable et llots do Nil à la condition que les terrea iuonltea renduea oultivables par lea travaux dans les limites des emplacements ohoisis, deviendront la propriltl de la Compagnie. Or, les travaux de rembl&yage commends en 1900, ont donnl dls 1901, dea rlsultats trie satisfaiaanta ; aotuellemeut one grande partie dea terrains amendls sont louls aux oultiva- teura indigknes à des prix rlmunlratenra, à Sobag, k Garf-Sarhan, Roda, Cheikh-Fadl Saadah, eto.

La Compagnie a aohetl et amlliorl jasqn'ioi 5443 feddans (dont 3.750 amlliorls, et 1873 achetls) pour lecqaels elle a dlbonrsl L<t, 147.980, soit Lst. 27.3.9. par feddan. On entrevoit le blnlfice laorme qui ponrra 6tre rlalisl lorsqae lea travaux seront complete- ment terminls.
Ea outre la Sooiltl poaakde 5,000 fed­dans de terrains achetla à la Dai'ra-Sanieh et dont elle a revendn one partie aveo un profit de Lst. 64.380.
La New Egyptian Co. poaalde auasi dea ter rains à b&tir au Caire, k Port-Sai'd.k Khartonm, achetls à des conditions trks avantageuses et qui ont acqnia une plus value conaidlrable.

E lfin la Now Egyptian a dea participations par voie d'apport on oomms foudatear, dans la Menzaleh Navigation Co., la Sadan Develop­ment & Exploration Co., l'lnternational Ethio­pian Railway Trast, TAnglo Amerioan Nile Navigation & Hotels .Co., TAnglo-Egyptian Lands Co.

En oonolusion, d'aprks une estimation iaite par les soins de personnalitls compltentes, il ressortirait que la plns-value acqnise par les propriltls de la Compagnie ne serait pa<* inflrieure à Lit. 100.000. div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
